snippet: The police arrested 141 people across New York City this week on charges that they bought stolen iPhones and iPads from undercover officers.
abstract: Police arrest 141 people in New York City on charges that they bought stolen iPhones and iPads from undercover police officers; sting operation is part of effort by Police Department to crack down on thefts of electronic devices.

headline.main: Buyers of Stolen Gadgets Are Arrested

snippet: After Research in Motion announced a delay in its new BlackBerry line and an intention to focus on promoting its existing phones, stocks fell to an eight-year low.
abstract: Research in Motion stock falls to eight-year low after it announces delay in its new BlackBerry line and an intention to focus on promoting its existing phones; analysts say no amount of advertising will help increase the sales of BlackBerrys in the United States because the current line is a jumble of too many models.

snippet: Tech journalists are picking apart the latest bad news from Research in Motion, maker of BlackBerry phones. On Thursday the company said that a new line of smartphones that it hoped would turn around its flagging fortunes would not come to market ...
abstract:
Tech journalists are picking apart the latest bad news from Research in Motion, maker of BlackBerry phones. On Thursday the company said that a new line of smartphones that it hoped would turn around its flagging fortunes would not come to market until late next year, Ian Austen reports.

A lot is riding on these phones because they will use an operating system known as BlackBerry 10, replacing the company’s older, aging software. They could be RIM’s last hope of reversing its fortunes, which have suffered as smartphones from Apple and devices running Google’s Android software have surged. The company also said that its third-quarter net income fell 71 percent as it chopped the price of its BlackBerry PlayBook tablet and covered the costs of a big service interruption.

Gizmodo says that the PlayBook, which has been met with a cold reception in the marketplace, is putting the whole company at risk: “It’s RIM’s Gilligan, albatross, and giant self-destruct button all rolled into one.” The tablet could be sucking up financial and personnel resources that the company needs to bolster its more viable products, according to Gizmodo.

Writing for PaidContent, Tom Krazit lays the blame on RIM’s co-chief executives, Jim Balsillie and Mike Lazaridis. He says they “failed to give anyone a reason to think RIM will be a player in mobile during 2012 or to explain why they should still have their jobs.”

Research in Motion shares were set to open about 10 percent lower on Friday.

headline.main: Daily Report: Research in Motion's Endless Struggles
